case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 301 to 319 and 1105 of 1969

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 301 to 319 and 1105 of 1969 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the order dated April 16, 1968 of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay in Applications Nos. LCB-28 of 1965 etc. Madan Mohan, for the appellants

facts.text: Order was of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay in Applications Nos. LCB-28 of 1965 etc.

anchor.surface_text: from the order dated April 16, 1968 of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay in Applications Nos. LCB-28 of 1965 etc. Madan Mohan, for the appellants  in all the appeals . K. Daphtary, O. P. Malhotra and K. L. Hathi, for respondents Nos. 1 and 2  in all the appeals .

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J. These appeals by special leave are directed against the order of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay, holding that the applications filed by the appellants against the Life Insurance Corporation of India under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,

facts.text: Applications filed by the appellants against the Life Insurance Corporation of India under s. 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave are directed against the order of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay, holding that the applications filed by the appellants against the Life Insurance Corporation of India under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, were barred under art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963, insofar -as the claim was for period beyond three years.

facts.text: Central Government Labour Court, Bombay held that the applications were barred under art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963 for claims beyond three years.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave are directed against the order of the Central Government Labour Court, Bombay, holding that the applications filed by the appellants against the Life Insurance Corporation of India under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, were barred under art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963, insofar -as the claim was for period beyond three years. In holding this the Labour Court followed the decision of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in The Manager M s. P. K. Porwal v. The Labour Court 1 .

facts.text: Labour Court followed the decision of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in The Manager M s. P. K. Porwal v. The Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: In holding this the Labour Court followed the decision of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in The Manager M s. P. K. Porwal v. The Labour Court 1 . The Bombay High Court held that applications filed under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act prior to its amendment by Central Act XXXVI of 1964 were governed by the period of limitation laid down in art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963,

facts.text: Bombay High Court held that applications under s. 33C(2) prior to amendment by Central Act XXXVI of 1964 were governed by art. 137 of Limitation Act, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court held that applications filed under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act prior to its amendment by Central Act XXXVI of 1964 were governed by the period of limitation laid down in art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963, and this article applied to applications under laws other than those companytained in the Civil Procedure Code, 1908.

facts.text: This Court in Town Municipal Council, Athani v. The Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Hubli dissented from the Bombay High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Town Municipal Council, Athani v. The Presid- ing Officer, Labour Court, Hubli   2   has dissented from the decision of the Bombay High Court and has held that art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963, does number apply to applications under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that art. 137 of Limitation Act, 1963 does not apply to applications under s. 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: has dissented from the decision of the Bombay High Court and has held that art. 137 of the Limitation Act, 1963, does number apply to applications under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act. This Court gave two reasons for companying to this companyclusion.

facts.text: Learned counsel for the respondent contends that applications should have been filed under s. 33C(1).

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the respondent companytends that the appeals should fail on -another ground. He says that these applications were filed under S. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, while they should have been filed under S. 33C 1 .

facts.text: Applications were for computing in terms of money the benefit of holidays and recovering the amount.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case applications were filed by the employees against the respondent for companyputing in terms of money the benefit of holidays and for recovering the amount. This case falls squarely within sub-s.  2  of S. 33C.

anchor.surface_text: This case falls squarely within sub-s.  2  of S. 33C. -There is numberaward or settlement under which the benefit of holidays had already been companyputed.

facts.text: Rules have been made including r. 62 of the Industrial Disputes Central Rules, 1957 providing for application in Form K-3.

anchor.surface_text: Rules have been made and r. 62 2  of the Industrial Disputes  Central  Rules, 1957, provides Where any workman or a group of workmen is entitled to receive from the employer any money or any benefit which is capable of being companyputed in terms of money, the workmen or the group of workmen, as the  1  1970 1 S.C.R. 51. case may be, may apply to the specified Labour Court in Form K-3

facts.text: Appeals are allowed and order of Labour Court set aside insofar as it held applications barred by art. 137.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are allowed and the order of the Labour Court set aside insofar as the Labour Court held that the applications were barred by art. 137 of the Limitation Act. The Labour Court will number pass the final order in accordance with law. The appellants will be entitled to their companyts, one hearing fee.
